**Five-Character Poem**
A cliff stands three thousand *ren* tall,
Its altar’s height brushes the Tail of the Winnowing Basket.
At its summit lies the marrow of green jade,
Around its waist hides the purple-gold *lingzhi*.
The moon hangs over the Palace of the Void Sovereign,
Clouds seal the Pool of the Great One.
A grotto-heaven where human traces are few,
Cranes nest on branches of ten thousand years.

**The First Grotto-Heaven of Lesser Clear Void**
Composed by Du Renjie of Qi

**Three-Character Lines**
What Earth bears,
What Heaven covers.
Form and image—
who first discerned their signs?
The Five Phases weave,
the Two Luminaries wheel.
Flowing as rivers—
how vast their expanse!
The Four Seas calm,
the Nine Rivers channeled.
Rising as mountains—
how many their names!
Divine are the peaks,
lofty the ranges.
Behold the Heavenly Altar,
the ultimate subtlety of the Dao.
Precipitous, solitary, towering—
not easily reached.
Sunrise and sunset
reveal its lingering glow.
East and west it spans,
cutting through the distant sea.
Sudden marvels of light
strike awe and dread.
Great dragon candles,
tiny fireflies’ glow.
Not always seen,
they appear at the call of resonance.
Clear and bright the reed pipes,
graceful the cranes’ dance.
The path of feathered immortals—
here lies its crux.
Mounds like green conches,
cliffs like jade hairpins.
To the left, Orion’s Well,
to the right, the Cinnabar Turtle.
Lifting the veil of Clear Void,
the peerless aperture.
Long ago, imperial envoys
came to proclaim its glory.
Since the days of the Yellow Emperor,
before the temples of Tang and Yu.
Linking the rites of firewood and prospect,
all offered personal sacrifices.
When the ashes of *mang* and *jie* were exhausted,
heavenly flames arose.
Halls and eaves collapsed,
crimson and azure hues lost.
Herds of deer and boars
mingled with reeds and brambles.
Why did I come?
To mourn this desolation.
Only when ruin is profound
does great creation begin.
The sage’s works,
the worthy’s continuations.
Delving into the profound mysteries of the Primordial,
their words arcane and abstruse.
The deeper the exploration,
the more radiant the principle.
Though the pattern is subtle,
it is no mere plagiarism.
May it endure henceforth,
a perpetual decree.

**Inscribed in the Fifth Month of the Twenty-Sixth Year of Zhiyuan**
*Record of the Jade Heavenly Worthy Bestowed by Imperial Favor*
Composed by Chen Daofu, Supervisor of Zhongyan

Now, the Heavenly Altar—since the Yellow Emperor’s time to the present, its lofty eminence has been unparalleled. Today, as the August Empress assumes the dragon throne, unifying the realm under shared script and harmonious winds and rains, with heaven and humanity in perfect accord, feudal lords come as guests, and all lands call her "Father." Thus, she commands the Grand Master of Court Audiences, Zhen Yongjian, to oversee the rites, bearing precious incense to the Heavenly Altar. With the ritual of triple libations, he invokes the deities, praying for the peace of the imperial house.

Moreover, this sacred mountain stands at the heart of Hua and Yi, crowning the grotto-heavens. Its peaks layer in emerald, its sheer cliffs towering, while dawn and dusk invert the light, and the two stars of Shen pierce the clearing sky. Auspicious creatures and divine beings seem scarcely within reach.

Yet as time flows and transformations shift, creation alters its course. Divine beings fade, mountains crumble—whereupon the official reports to the Empress Dowager. Her sagely decree declares: "This is the land of the dragon’s rise, the spirit of our nation. It is our duty; it must not be abandoned." She orders artisans to carve a jade image, honoring the sacred, and commands the Grand Master of Instruction, Wu Tianyou, to bear the jade likeness and sacred relics, enshrining them in the grotto-heaven to eternally safeguard the imperial domain, as steadfast as Mount Tai’s foundation, as boundless as the Bohai’s expanse.

The director of this temple, Ning Zhu, entrusted me, Wan Jisen, to record this grandeur. Thus, I extol and inscribe: the jade soars, resplendent as the Emperor of the Primordial; the imperial grace uniquely bestows its blessing upon the mountains and rivers. The sagely court’s abundance is near at hand—may our sovereign’s reign endure for a hundred million years.
